speaker: Colonel Duval

utterance: "There's your rations,"
speaker: the sergeant

utterance: "Men,”
speaker: the old Colonel

utterance: "My men, I cannot let you go so. We were neighbors when the war began-many of us, and some not here to-night; we have been more since then-comrades, brothers in arms; we have all stood for one thing-for Virginia and the South; we have all done our duty-tried to do our duty; we have fought a good fight, and now it seems to be over, and we have been overwhelmed by numbers, not whipped-and we are going home. We have the future before us-we don't know just what it will bring, but we can stand a good deal. We have proved it. Upon us depends the South in the future as in the past. You have done your duty in the past, you will not fail in the future. Go home and be honest, brave, self-sacrificing, God-fearing citizens, as you have been soldiers, and you need not fear for Virginia and the South. The war may be over; but you will ever be ready to serve your country. The end may not be as we wanted it, prayed for it, fought for it; but we can trust God; the end in the end will be the best that could be; even if the South is not free she will be better and stronger that she fought as she did. Go home and bring up your children to love her, and though you may have nothing else to leave them, you can leave them the heritage that they are sons of men who were in Lee's army."
speaker: the old Colonel

utterance: "What is it, Harris?"
speaker: the Colonel

utterance: "If you please, sir, we have been talking it over, and we 'd like this paper to go in along with that you 're writing."

speaker: Harris

utterance: "What is it?"
speaker: the Colonel

utterance: "It's just a little list we made out in and among us, with a few things we 'd like to put in, so 's if anyone ever hauls 'em out they'll find it there to tell what the old battery was, and if they don't, it 'll be in one of 'em down thar 'til judgment, an' it 'll sort of ease our minds a bit."
speaker: Harris

utterance: "Will you sort of look over it, sir, if you think it's worth while? We was in a sort of hurry and we had to put it down just as we come to it; we did n't have time to pick our ammunition; and it ain't written the best in the world, nohow."

speaker: Vashti

I knowed it was a lie too, and he knowed I knowed it was a lie-what's more-and I'm glad he did-fo' God I'm glad he did. He could 'a' whipped the whole company an' he jest would n't-an' that 's God's truth-God's fatal truth.

speaker: Dick Rail

utterance:
we were late, and I was just shaking 'em up.
I had been meaner 'n hell to Jim all the trip (I did n't know him, and you all didn't neither), and I was workin' him for all he was worth: I did n't give him a minute. The sweat was rolling off him, an I was damnin' him with every shovelful. We was runnin' under orders to make up, and we was just rounding the curve this side of Ridge Hill, when Jim hollered. He saw it as he raised up with the shovel in his hand to wipe the sweat off his face, and he hollered to me, 'My God! Look, Dick! Jump!'
I looked and Hell was right there. He caught the lever and reversed, and put on the air and sand before I saw it, and then grabbed me, and flung me clean out of the cab: 'Jump!'
he says, as he give me a swing. I jumped, expectin' of course he was comin' too; and as I lit, I saw him turn and catch the lever. The old engine was jumpin' nigh off the track. But she was too near. In she went, and the tender right on her. You may talk about his eyes bein'
bad; but by -! when he gave me that swing, they looked to me like coals of fire. When we got him out 't warn't Jim. He warn't nothin'
but mud and ashes. He warn't quite dead; opened his eyes, and breathed onct or twict; but I don't think he knew anything, he was so mashed up. We laid him out on the grass, and that young lady took his head in her lap and cried over him (she had come and seed him in the engine), and said she knew his mother and sister down in the country (she used to live down there); they was gentlefolks; that Jim was all they had. And when one of them old directorfellows who had been swilling himself behind there come aroun', with his kid gloves on and his hands in his great-coat pockets, lookin' down, and sayin' something about, 'Poor fellow, couldn't he 'a jumped? Why did n't he jump?'
I let him have it; I said, 'Yes, and if it had n't been for him, you and I 'd both been frizzin' in h-l this minute.' And the President standin'
there said to some of them, "That was the same young fellow who came into my office to get a place last year when you were down, and said he had "run to seed."'But,' he says, 'Gentlemen, it was d--d good seed!'

utterance:
He was a most charming man, my dear, and to think of it, I don't believe I had looked in a glass all day, and when I got here, my cap had somehow got twisted around and was perched right over my left ear, making me look a perfect fright. He told me his name, but I have forgotten it, of course. But he was such a gentleman, and to think of his being a Yankee!
I told him I hated all Yankees, and he just laughed, and did not mind my stick, nor old umbrella, nor bundles, a bit. You'd have thought my old cap was a Parisian bonnet. I will not believe he was a Yankee.

speaker: George Washington

utterance: If you will permit me to inquire, Uncle George, how old are you?

speaker: George Washington

utterance: Oh!
speaker: Miss Jemima

utterance: Marse Nat kin tell you, if you don't know how ole you is, all you got to do is to ax him, an' he kin tell you-he got it all set down in a book-he kin tell how ole you is to a day.
speaker: George Washington

utterance: Dear, how frightful!
speaker: Miss Jemima

utterance: Major, your valet appears to be a very intelligent person.
speaker: Miss Jemima

utterance: My 'valet!' Madam! I have no valet!
speaker: Major

utterance: I mean your body servant, your butler
speaker: Miss Jemima

utterance: I have been much impressed by him.
speaker: Miss Jemima

utterance: George!—George Washington?—you mean George Washington! No, madam, he has not a particle of intelligence. He is grossly and densely stupid. I have never in fifty years been able to get an idea into his head.
speaker: Major

utterance: Oh, dear! and I thought him so clever! I was wondering how so intelligent a person, so well informed, could be a slave.
speaker: Miss Jemima

utterance: George! George Washington a slave! Madam, you misapprehend the situation. He is no slave. I am the slave, not only of him but of three hundred more as arrogant and exacting as the Czar, and as lazy as the devil!
speaker: Major

utterance: Why, madam, the very coat on my back belongs to that rascal George Washington, and I do not know when he may take a fancy to order me out of it. My soul is not my own. He drinks my whisky, steals my tobacco, and takes my clothes before my face. As likely as not he will have on this very waistcoat before the week is out.
speaker: Major

utterance: Oh, dear! You amaze me
speaker: Miss Jemima

utterance: Yes, madam, I should be amazed myself, except that I have stood it so long. Why, I had once an affair with an intimate and valued friend, Judge Carrington. You may have heard of him, a very distinguished man! and I was indiscreet enough to carry that rascal George Washington to the field, thinking, of course, that I ought to go like a gentleman, and although the affair was arranged after we had taken our positions, and I did not have the pleasure of shooting at him
speaker: Major

utterance: The pleasure of shooting at your friend! Monstrous!

utterance: We hit him fyah an' squar'.

utterance: Done, madam?
speaker: the Major

utterance: Yes; what have you done to that poor miserable creature there!
speaker: Miss Jemima Bridges

utterance: What have I been doing with him?
speaker: the Major

utterance: Yes, with him. Have you been carrying out your barbarous rite on his inoffensive person!
speaker: Miss Jemima Bridges

utterance:
Yes, madam, and I rejoice that you are here to witness its successful termination. George open Washington has been selected as the victim this year; his monstrous lies, his habitual drunken worthlessness, his roguery, culminating in the theft to-day of my best coat and waistcoat, marked him naturally as the proper sacrifice.
I had not the heart to cheat any one by selling him to him. I was therefore constrained to shoot him. He was, with his usual triflingness, not killed at the first fire, although he appears to be dead. I will now finish him by putting a ball into his back; observe the shot.
speaker: the Major

Oh! it is not worth anything as land, but I love the association. My mother was brought up there, and I keep up the garden just as it was.
You shall have the roses. Some day I want to Just then there was a see you among them.

utterance: Newton, anybody would know that you were a Virginian, by the way you stand before that fire.
speaker: McPheeters

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Newton

utterance: I was just thinking how good it felt, and I had gone back and was standing in the old parlor at home the first time I ever noticed my father doing it; I remember getting up and standing by him, a little scrap of a fellow, trying to stand just as he did, and I was feeling the fire, just now, just as I did that night. That was-thirty-three years ago.
speaker: Newton

utterance: Newton, is your father living?
speaker: Lesponts

utterance: No, but my mother is; she still lives at the old home in the country.
speaker: Newton

utterance: Did any of you ever spend a Christmas on the cars? If you have not, thank Heaven, and pray to be preserved from it henceforth, for I 've done it, and I tell you it's next to purgatory. I spent one once, stuck in a snow-drift, or almost stuck, for we were ten hours late, and missed all connections, and the Christmas I had expected to spend with friends, I passed in a nasty car with a surly Pullman conductor, an impudent mulatto porter, and a lot of fools, all of whom could have murdered each other, not to speak of a crying baby whose murder was perhaps the only thing all would have united on.
speaker: one of the men

utterance: Yes, I have spent a Christmas on a sleeping-car, and, strange to say, I have a most delightful recollection of it.
speaker: Lesponts

utterance: Has any of you ever taken the night train that goes from here South through the Cumberland and Shenandoah Valleys, or from Washington to strike that train?
speaker: Lesponts

utterance: Well, do it, and you can even do it Christmas, if you get the right conductor. It's well worth doing the first chance you get, for it 's almost the prettiest country in the world that you go through; there is nothing that I've ever seen lovelier than parts of the Cumberland and Shenandoah Valleys, and the New River Valley is just as pretty,-that background of blue beyond those rolling hills, and all,-you know, McPheeters?
speaker: Lesponts

utterance: I'm not positive, but I think there's a train on such and such a road, and you may be able to get a berth on that. It leaves about this time, and if you hurry you may be able to catch it.
speaker: ticket agent

utterance: Yes, you've just about time to stand a chance; everything is late to-day, there are wall mount made And he get such crowds, and the snow and all.

utterance: You asked me if the lower berths were all taken, did you not?

utterance: Yes, five minutes ago!

utterance: Well, they are all taken, just as they were the first time I told you they were.
speaker: old Captain

utterance: New Orleans!
speaker: old Captain

utterance:
I told you that I would give you a lower berth, sir, I can give you one now, I have just got a message that the person who had "lower two"
will not want it.
speaker: old Captain
addressee: the fellow who had made the row about the lower berth

utterance: Hold on, then, I'll take that lower, I spoke for it first.
speaker: the fellow who had made the row about the lower berth

utterance: No you won't.
speaker: old Captain
addressee: the fellow who had made the row about the lower berth

utterance:
What 's that?
I did, I say. I was here before that man got here, and asked you for a lower berth, and you said they were all taken.
speaker: the fellow who had made the row about the lower berth

utterance: My dear sir, I know you did; but this gentleman has a lady along.
speaker: old Captain
addressee: the fellow who had made the row about the lower berth

utterance: I don't care, I engaged the berth and I know my rights; I mean to have that lower berth, or I'll see which is bigger, you or Mr. Pullman.
speaker: the fellow who had made the row about the lower berth

utterance: My dear madam, you are all right, just go in there and take your seat anywhere; when I come in I will fix everything. Go straight into that car and don't come out in this cold air any more.
speaker: old Captain

utterance: Nick, go in there and seat that lady, if you have to turn every man out of his seat.
speaker: old Captain

utterance: Now, my dear sir, you don't mean that: you'd be the first man to give up your berth; this gentleman has his sick wife with him and has been ordered to take her South immediately, and she 's going to have a lower berth if I turn every man in that car out, and if you were Mr. Pullman himself I'd tell you the same thing.
speaker: old Captain
addressee: the fellow who had made the row about the lower berth

utterance: to give you a little more light on your book, sir.
speaker: old Captain

utterance: to shut out a little of the glare, madam-reading on the cars is a little more trying to the eyes than one is apt to fancy.
speaker: old Captain

utterance:
Yes, sir, he 's a very good boy; I raised him, or rather, my father did; he comes of a good stock; plenty of sense and know their places. When I came on the road they gave me a mulatto fellow whom I couldn't stand, one of these young, new, "free-issue"
some call them, sir, I believe; I could n't stand him; I got rid of him. I asked him what was the trouble. 'Oh! no trouble at all, sir; he just did n't know his place, and I taught him. He could read and write a little-a negro is very apt to think, sir, that if he can write he is educated-he could write, and thought he was educated; he chewed a toothpick and thought he was a gentleman. I soon taught him better.
He was impertinent, and I put him off the train.
After that I told them that I must have my own servant if I was to remain with them, and I got Nick. He is an excellent boy (he was about fifty-five). The black is a capital servant, sir, when he has sense, far better than the mulatto.
speaker: old Captain

utterance: Got a sweetheart there?
speaker: old Captain

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Lesponts

utterance: Ah! you lucky dog.
speaker: old Captain

utterance: You tell her I say you'll be all right.
speaker: old Captain

utterance: I'll tell her so myself.
speaker: old Captain

utterance: I always said if I could find that Yankee that shot me I 'd like to make him a present.
speaker: old Captain

utterance: are you afraid of her?
speaker: old Captain

utterance:
Well, sir, it will never do; you must n't let her think that never. You cannot help being afraid of her, for every man is that; but it is fatal to let her know it.
Stand up, sir, stand up for your rights. If you are bound to get down on your knees-and every man feels that he is-don't do it; get up and run out and roll in the dust outside somewhere where she can't see you. Why, sir, it does n't do to even let her think she 's having her own way; half the time she 's only testing you, and she does n't really want what she pretends to want. Of course, I'm speaking of before marriage; after marriage she always wants it, and she 's going to have it, anyway, and the sooner you find that out and give in, the better. You must consider this, however, that her way after marriage is always laid down to her with reference to your good.
She thinks about you a great deal more than you do about her, and she 's always working out something that is for your advantage; she 'll let you do some things as you wish, just to make you believe you are having your own way, but she's just been pretending to think otherwise, to make you feel good.
speaker: old Captain

utterance: Stand, sir? why, everything, everything that does not take away his self-respect.
speaker: old Captain

utterance: why, of course she will, and why should n't she? A man is not good enough for a good woman to wipe her shoes on. But if she's the right sort of a woman she won't do it in company, and she won't let others do it at all; she 'll keep you for her own wiping.
speaker: old Captain

utterance: There's a lot of sense in that, Lesponts.
speaker: one of his auditors

utterance: find any of them out to-day, as it was Christmas, and they would all be at home.
speaker: old Captain

utterance: There he is, now!
speaker: someone

utterance: We were going to give you a big funeral, Captain, they 've got you while you are living, but we claim you when you are dead. We ain't going to let 'em have you then. We're going to put you to sleep in old Virginia.
speaker: one old fellow

utterance: Gentlemen, these are my boys, my neighbors and family; Boys, these are my friends; I don't know all their names yet, but they are my friends.
speaker: old Captain

utterance: the materials
speaker: old Captain

utterance: And, gentlemen, there are two toasts I always like to propose at this time, and which I will ask you to drink. The first is to my wife.
speaker: old Captain

utterance: My friends: all mankind.
speaker: old Captain

utterance: Why, Captain, you are not drinking! that is not fair.
speaker: someone

utterance: Well, no, sir, I never drink anything on duty; you see, it is one of the regulations, and I subscribed them, and, of course, I could not break my word. Nick, there, will drink my share, however, when you are through; he is n't held up to quite such high accountability.
speaker: old Captain

utterance: Captain, is she here?
speaker: Lesponts

utterance: Yes, sir, she is, she never misses; that 's the sort of a wife to have, sir; come here and let me introduce you.
speaker: old Captain

utterance: My dear, this is my friend, Mr. Lesponts, and he has promised to come and dine with us.
speaker: old Captain

utterance: Why, she's coming to dine with us to-day.
speaker: the Captain's wife

utterance: I saved Christmas dinner for you; for when you didn't come I knew the calendar and all the rest of the world were wrong; so to-day is our Christmas.
speaker: the Captain's wife

utterance: Lesponts, why did n't you fellows get him some better place?
speaker: One of them
